clinical_study.brief_title: Wearable Skin Sensors to Assess Nocturnal Scratch Behavior
clinical_study.official_title: A Single Arm, Prospective Clinical Study Using Novel Wearable Sensors to Assess the Improvement of Nocturnal Scratch Behavior and Sleep Quality in Children With Mild-to-moderate Atopic Dermatitis Treated With Topical Crisaborole

brief_summary.textblock: Pilot study of flexible and wearable sensor to monitor nocturnal scratching behavior

detailed_description.textblock: Present an advanced flexible, and wearable sensor intimately coupled to the skin that can measure the full spectrum of relevant physiological parameters associated with atopic dermatitis including scratch count, scratch duration, scratch intensity, heart rate, heart rate variability and respiratory rate.

primary_outcome.measure: Percent agreement of scratching between the experimental sensor and the infrared camera

secondary_outcome.measure: Improvement of sleep parameters (time asleep) measured by the experimental sensor during treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Baseline compared to treatment time points will be compared in units of time (minutes/hours)

secondary_outcome.measure: Improvement of sleep parameters (time until onset of sleep) measured by the experimental sensor
secondary_outcome.description: Baseline compared to treatment time points will be compared in units of time (minutes/hours)

secondary_outcome.measure: Improvement of sleep parameters (heart rate) measured by the experimental sensor
secondary_outcome.description: Baseline compared to treatment time points will be compared in units of beats/min

secondary_outcome.measure: Improvement of sleep parameters (respiratory rate) measured by the experimental sensor
secondary_outcome.description: Baseline compared to treatment time points will be compared in units of breaths/min.

arm_group.description: Subjects will apply topical crisaborole twice daily to the affected atopic dermatitis areas for three weeks.

intervention.description: Subject to apply topical crisaborole twice daily to the affected atopic dermatitis areas
advanced, flexible and wearable skin sensor

study_pop.textblock: Participants with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Participants with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis ages 2 years or older. This will be determined by clinical diagnosis of AD according to the Hanifin and Rajka criteria with a baseline Investigators Global Assessment score of mild (2) or moderate (3)
- Systemic therapy use (e.g. oral corticosteroid, cyclosporine, methotrexate, phototherapy) within 28 days of subject enrollment
- Topical corticosteroid use or topical calcineurin inhibitor use within 14 days of subject enrollment
- Willingness and ability to set up an infrared video camera nightly
- Willing to apply topical crisaborole twice daily to affected atopic dermatitis areas of the body
Exclusion Criteria:
- Active skin or systemic infection
- Inability to operate a smartphone or video camera
- Active atopic dermatitis on he dorsum of the hand or suprasternal notch
